7.text: Zoja: And hi, my name’s Zoja

8.text:
Miranda: We’re from the National Portrait
Gallery Youth Forum.

11.text:
Zoja: We’re here right now in the National
Portrait Gallery about to give a talk about

15.text:
the Van Dyck: Transforming British Art exhibition,
which is right behind us… hope you enjoy it!

21.text:
Miranda: So if I can take you over the centrepiece
here, which is Van Dyck’s Self-portrait.

25.text:
Self-portraiture at the time was a very radical
act. It was the 17th century, where being

29.text: an artist was very much a commercial vocation.

31.text:
Van Dyck was very much a I'm a celebretary
portrait artist. He had people queuing up

36.text:
to buy his paintings because he was so successful.
Here Van Dyck is drawing attention to himself

41.text:
and the role of the artist. Then, is was very
radical, very uncommon; whereas if we look

45.text:
at contemporary artists such as Tracey Emin,
it’s very raw, very self-confessional and

51.text:
often controversial, so it has a completely
different aim where the viewer is invited

56.text:
to judge and make an assumption on the artist’s
personality; whereas here it’s more to transcend

64.text:
the status of the artist.
We’re very used to consuming and projecting

67.text:
images of ourselves such as on social media.
‘Selfies' are obviously very popular; whereas

73.text:
the aim then might be in a sense similar
to this one where you’re trying to elevate

80.text:
Josh: Portraiture itself had become out of
vogue and self-portraiture even rarer, but

87.text:
Van Dyck transformed it bringing in a sense
perspectival space where before the paintings

94.text:
had been flat, he brought in a sense of emotion
where before they’d been expressionless

99.text:
and a sense of movement where before they’d
been still and staid.

103.text:
He conveyed the sense of movement through
the posture, which is contrapposto in this

109.text:
painting, which is essentially this [shows
posture]. So we feel the movement of him turning

116.text: his head around as if to greet us as the viewers.

118.text:
Zoja: I want to first ask you what do you
think portraiture is? Is it the recording

123.text:
of an individual’s appearance and personality,
or does it represent power, importance and

129.text:
virtue and other qualities of the sitter,
as seen here by Van Dyck?

133.text:
It’s his pose and stature – and obviously
the frame – which gives off the impression

138.text:
that he was trying to flatter himself.
Portraits have almost always been flattering.

143.text:
Contemporary painters who refuse to flatter
often find their work frowned upon or simply

148.text:
disregarded due to its controversy.
What have sparked many questions in art historians’

153.text:
minds are his clothes. Take a glance at the
heaviness and roughness of these brushstrokes

158.text:
in comparison to the face, which is smooth
and finely detailed. Is this painting simply

164.text:
unfinished or was Van Dyck experimenting with
a new style?

167.text:
Elly: There were no manufactured oil paints
at the time. Therefore him and his assistants

171.text:
would have had to make their own paints from
scratch. This would have been done using pigments

176.text:
such as vermillion red and oil crutched up
with a pestle and motor. This pigment is called

180.text:
ultramarine blue, which was extremely rare
and expensive; and therefore if you can see

185.text:
blue in paintings – here you can see it
on the shoulder – it signifies status and

191.text:
wealth.
The canvas would have been made with a primer

196.text:
of rabbit skin glue, which, as it may suggest,
is made of rabbit skin. And then, the frame

204.text:
which we’ve brought here today – which
you’re all welcome to come and have a look

208.text:
at later – shows the three stages of its
preparation: this would have been the wooden

215.text:
carving, secondly the plaster and then finished
with the gold leaf.

220.text:
Van Dyck’s frame is thought to have been
specifically made for this painting, and that’s

226.text: another thing that you can think about today,

228.text: is whether the frame that he has chosen adds

231.text:
to the positioning and the composition of
the painting.
